item.title: Iterative DNS Brute Forcing
item.description: Everyone has their list of hostnames they brute force domains with. In my last post I even mentioned a few ways to use one with XARGS or PARALLEL. But one fact about wordlist brute forcing is that there is no “one list to rule them all”. But over the years of doing DNS record collection I have noticed one thing, most domains have a large number of short hostnames that are easy to remember, usually 4 characters or less.

item.title: Hostname bruteforcing on the cheap
item.description: Quick update: As @MikeDamm points out, xargs has a -P option that can do the same thing I’m using parallel for. If you have a supported version of xargs you can use -P 0 to do the same thing as -j0 with parallel, but if your version doesn’t support the 0 you can simply use the same number parallel uses ala: cat subdomains.txt | xargs -P 122 -I subdomain dig +noall subdomain.

item.title: Changing proxychains hardcoded DNS server
item.description: If you’ve ever used proxychains to push things through Meterpreter, one of the most annoying things is its “hardcoded” DNS setting for 4.2.2.2, if the org that you are going after doesn’t allow this out of their network, or if you are trying to resolve an internal asset, you’re SOL. After a ton of googling and annoyed head slams into walls every time I forget where this is I’ve finally decided to make a note of it.

item.title: AXFR for DNSSEC: DNSSEC Walker
item.description: TL;DR – DNSSEC Walker traverses a domain’s DNSSEC records to locate it’s regular DNS records. I like to go through slides of cons I can’t make it out to, and Hack-in-the-Box (HITB) Kul (Malaysia), was one such as they were very quick to release sides: http://conference.hitb.org/hitbsecconf2011kul/materials/ One that I came across is Marc “van Hauser” Heuse’s talk on IPv6 titled “IPv6 Insecurity Revolutions” (Link directly to PDF on aforementioned materials link).

item.title: A @textfiles approach at gathering the world's DNS - Slides
item.description: This is my talk that I gave at ShmooCon 2012. It was a great honor to be given the chance to speak at ShmooCon as it has been my second home since 2006 (missed the first one… havent missed one since) A @textfiles approach to gathering the world's DNS from Rob Fuller

item.title: Interesting DNS Stuff - SRV Records
item.description: The following are good adds to your DNS brute force list: These are all SRV records so make sure your type is set correctly. The great thing about SRV records is that it tells you the port in the answer. Isn’t that nice of them? I don’t know of any DNS tools that utilize SRV as part of their process, but scripting dig to do so isn’t tough. _autodiscover._tcp _caldav._tcp _client.

item.title: OzymanDNS - Tunneling SSH over DNS
item.description: Hak5 Episode 504 Shownotes (In the episode I say that it’s cross platform, use the release links for the Windows binaries to get it working on windows or use cygwin) DISCLAIMER - I IN NO WAY ENDORSE ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES - USE THE FOLLOWING GUIDE IN A TEST ENVIRONMENT OR AT YOUR OWN LEGAL RISK. UPDATE:Thanks to Chris Gates and Robin Wood for pointing me towards a fixed up version of OzymanDNS and a great tutorial: HERE
